introduction.p: Models for real situations are often variations of the basic functions introduced in . In this section, we explore how certain changes in the formula for a function affect its graph. In particular, we will compare the graph of y = f (x) with the graphs of y = f (x) + k,~~~~ y = f (x + h),~~~ \text{ and }~~~ y = a f (x) for different values of the constants k, h, and a. Such variations are called transformationstransformations of the graph.

subsection.title: Vertical Translations
subsection.p: shows the graphs of f (x) = x^2 + 4, g(x) = x^2 - 4, and the basic parabola, y = x^2. By comparing tables of values, we can see exactly how the graphs of f and g are related to the basic parabola.

Each y-value in the table for f (x) is four units greater than the corresponding y-value for the basic parabola. Consequently, each point on the graph of f (x) is four units higher than the corresponding point on the basic parabola, as shown by the arrows. Similarly, each point on the graph of g(x) is four units lower than the corresponding point on the basic parabola.

The graphs of y = f (x) and y = g(x) are said to be translationstranslations of the graph of y = x^2. They are shifted to a different location in the plane but retain the same size and shape as the original graph. In general, we have the following principles.

assemblage.title: Vertical Translations
assemblage.p:
Compared with the graph of y = f (x),
The graph of y=f(x)+k (k\gt 0) is shifted upward k units.
The graph of y=f(x)-k (k\gt 0) is shifted downward k units.

statement.p: An evaporative cooler, or swamp cooler, is an energy-efficient type of air conditioner used in dry climates. A typical swamp cooler can reduce the temperature inside a house by 15 degrees. a shows the graph of T = f (t), the temperature inside Kate's house t hours after she turns on the swamp cooler. Write a formula in terms of f for the function g shown in b and, give a possible explanation of its meaning.

answer.p: g(t) = f (t) + 10. The outside temperature was 10\degree hotter.

subsection.title: Horizontal Translations
subsection.p: Now consider the graphs of f (x) = (x + 2)^2 and g(x) = (x - 2)^2 shown in . Compared with the graph of the basic function y = x^2, the graph of f (x) = (x + 2)^2 is shifted two units to the left, as shown by the arrows. You can see why this happens by studying the function values in the table.

Locate a particular y-value for y = x^2, say, y = 4. You must move two units to the left in the table to find the same y-value for f (x), as shown by the arrow. In fact, each y-value for f (x) occurs two units to the left when compared to the same y-value for y = x^2.

Similarly, the graph of g(x) = (x - 2)^2 is shifted two units to the right compared to the graph of y = x^2. In the table for g, each y-value for g(x) occurs two units to the right of the same y-value for y = x^2. In general, we have the following principle.

assemblage.title: Horizontal Translations
assemblage.p:
Compared with the graph of y = f (x),
The graph of y = f (x + h)~ ~ (h \gt 0) is shifted h units to the left.
The graph of y = f (x - h)~ ~ (h \gt 0) is shifted h units to the right.

note.p: At first, the direction of a horizontal translation may seem counterintuitive. Look again at the tables above to help you see how the shift occurs.

sidebyside.p: The function N = f (p) graphed in gives the number of people who have a given eye pressure level p from a sample of 100 people with healthy eyes, and the function g gives the number of people with pressure level p in a sample of 100 glaucoma patients.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Write a formula for g as a transformation of f.
For what pressure readings could a doctor be fairly certain that a patient has glaucoma?

ol.label: a
ol.li: The graph of g is translated 10 units to the right of f, so g(p) = f (p - 10).
Pressure readings above 40 are a strong indication of glaucoma. Readings between 10 and 40 cannot conclusively distinguish healthy eyes from those with glaucoma.

statement.p: The function C = f (t) in gives the caffeine level in Delbert's bloodstream at time t hours after he drinks a cup of coffee, and g(t) gives the caffeine level in Francine's bloodstream. Write a formula for g in terms of f, and explain what it tells you about Delbert and Francine.

answer.p: g(t) = f (t - 3). Francine drank her coffee 3 hours after Delbert drank his.

subsection.title: Scale Factors
subsection.p:
We have seen that adding a constant to the expression defining a function results in a translation of its graph. What happens if we multiply the expression by a constant? Consider the graphs of the functions
f(x)= 2x^2 \text{, } ~g(x)= \frac{1}{2}x^2 \text{, and } ~h(x) = -x^2
shown in , , and , and compare each to the graph of y = x^2.

Compared to the graph of y = x^2, the graph of f (x) = 2x^2 is expanded, or stretched, vertically by a factor of 2. The y-coordinate of each point on the graph has been doubled, as you can see in the table of values, so each point on the graph of f is twice as far from the x-axis as its counterpart on the basic graph y = x^2.
The graph of g(x) = \dfrac{1}{2}x^2 is compressed vertically by a factor of \dfrac{1}{2}; each point is half as far from the x-axis as its counterpart on the graph of y = x^2.
The graph of h(x) = -x^2 is flipped, or reflected, about the x-axis; the y-coordinate of each point on the graph of y = x^2 is replaced by its opposite.
In general, we have the following principles.

assemblage.title: Scale Factors and Reflections
assemblage.p:
Compared with the graph of y = f (x), the graph of y = a f (x), where a \ne 0, is
stretched vertically by a factor of \abs{a} if \abs{a}\gt 1,
compressed vertically by a factor of \abs{a} if 0\lt\abs{a}\lt 1, and
reflected about the x-axis if a\lt 0.

li.p: The graph of g(x) = 3\sqrt[3]{x} is a vertical expansion of the basic graph y = \sqrt[3]{x} by a factor of 3, as shown in . Each point on the basic graph has its y-coordinate tripled.

The graph of h(x) = \dfrac{-1}{2}\abs{x} is a vertical compression of the basic graph y = \abs{x} by a factor of \dfrac{1}{2}, combined with a reflection about the x-axis. You may find it helpful to graph the function in two steps, as shown in .

ol.li: How is the graph of f different from the graph of y =\abs{x}?

li.p: Stretch y =\abs{x} vertically by a factor of 2.

statement.p: The function A = f (t) graphed in gives a person's blood alcohol level t hours after drinking a martini. Sketch a graph of g(t) = 2 f (t) and explain what it tells you.

solution.p: To sketch a graph of g, we stretch the graph of f vertically by a factor of 2, as shown in . At each time t, the person's blood alcohol level is twice the value given by f. The function g could represent a person's blood alcohol level t hours after drinking two martinis.

statement.p: If the Earth were not tilted on its axis, there would be 12 daylight hours every day all over the planet. But in fact, the length of a day in a particular location depends on the latitude and the time of year.

The graph in shows H = f (t), the length of a day in Helsinki, Finland, t days after January 1, and R = g(t), the length of a day in Rome. Each is expressed as the number of hours greater or less than 12. Write a formula for f in terms of g. What does this formula tell you?

answer.p: f (t)\approx 2g(t). On any given day, the number of daylight hours varies from 12 hours about twice as much in Helsinki as it does in Rome.
